natural problem: 4 12-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that the number of dice showing a two digit number is equal to the number of dice showing a one digit number? Express your answer as a common fraction. (Assume that the numbers on the 12 sides are the numbers from 1 to 12 expressed in decimal.)
natural solution: Since 9 out of the 12 possible results are one digit numbers, each die will show a one digit number with probability of $\frac{3}{4}$ and a two digit number with probability of $\frac{1}{4}$. The probability that two particular dice will show 2 two digit numbers and 2 one digit numbers is thus $\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^2\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^2$.

There are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ ways to select which two dice will show one digit numbers, so we multiply to get the probability that we want: $6\cdot\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^2\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^2=\dfrac{54}{256}=\boxed{\dfrac{27}{128}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum>i = 0..4. (binomial 4 i) * (9 / 12) ^ i * (3 / 12) ^ (4 - i))"
shows  "P = 27 / 128"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 4 12-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that the number of dice showing a two digit number is equal to the number of dice showing a one digit number? Express your answer as a common fraction. (Assume that the numbers on the 12 sides are the numbers from 1 to 12 expressed in decimal.) The final Answer is \dfrac{27}{128}
 ### Proof
 Since 9 out of the 12 possible results are one digit numbers, each die will show a one digit number with probability of $\frac{3}{4}$ and a two digit number with probability of $\frac{1}{4}$. The probability that two particular dice will show 2 two digit numbers and 2 one digit numbers is thus $\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^2\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^2$.
 There are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ ways to select which two dice will show one digit numbers, so we multiply to get the probability that we want: $6\cdot\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^2\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^2=\dfrac{54}{256}=\boxed{\dfrac{27}{128}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum>i = 0..4. (binomial 4 i) * (9 / 12) ^ i * (3 / 12) ^ (4 - i))"
shows  "P = 27 / 128"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the probability $P$ of obtaining exactly $i$ successes in 4 Bernoulli trials with a success probability of $\frac{9}{12}$ and a failure probability of $\frac{3}{12}$. The final answer is $\frac{27}{128}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = 27 / 128"
shows  "p = (3 / 12) powr 4"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 4 12-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that the number of dice showing a two digit number is equal to the number of dice showing a one digit number? Express your answer as a common fraction. (Assume that the numbers on the 12 sides are the numbers from 1 to 12 expressed in decimal.) The final Answer is \dfrac{27}{128}
 ### Proof
 Since 9 out of the 12 possible results are one digit numbers, each die will show a one digit number with probability of $\frac{3}{4}$ and a two digit number with probability of $\frac{1}{4}$. The probability that two particular dice will show 2 two digit numbers and 2 one digit numbers is thus $\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^2\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^2$.
 There are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ ways to select which two dice will show one digit numbers, so we multiply to get the probability that we want: $6\cdot\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^2\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^2=\dfrac{54}{256}=\boxed{\dfrac{27}{128}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = 27 / 128"
shows  "p = (3 / 12) powr 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: What is the value of $p$ if $p = (\frac{3}{12})^4$? The final answer is $\frac{27}{128}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes num_dice :: nat
and num_sides :: nat
and num_twodigit :: nat
and num_onedigit :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_dice = 4"
and h1 : "num_sides = 12"
and h2 : "num_twodigit = 2"
and h3 : "num_onedigit = 2"
shows  "probability (num_twodigit = num_onedigit) = 27 / 128"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 4 12-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that the number of dice showing a two digit number is equal to the number of dice showing a one digit number? Express your answer as a common fraction. (Assume that the numbers on the 12 sides are the numbers from 1 to 12 expressed in decimal.) The final Answer is \dfrac{27}{128}
 ### Proof
 Since 9 out of the 12 possible results are one digit numbers, each die will show a one digit number with probability of $\frac{3}{4}$ and a two digit number with probability of $\frac{1}{4}$. The probability that two particular dice will show 2 two digit numbers and 2 one digit numbers is thus $\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^2\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^2$.
 There are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ ways to select which two dice will show one digit numbers, so we multiply to get the probability that we want: $6\cdot\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^2\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^2=\dfrac{54}{256}=\boxed{\dfrac{27}{128}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes num_dice :: nat
and num_sides :: nat
and num_twodigit :: nat
and num_onedigit :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_dice = 4"
and h1 : "num_sides = 12"
and h2 : "num_twodigit = 2"
and h3 : "num_onedigit = 2"
shows  "probability (num_twodigit = num_onedigit) = 27 / 128"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In a game, you roll 4 twelve-sided dice. What is the probability that the number of two-digit numbers rolled is equal to the number of one-digit numbers rolled? The final answer is $\frac{27}{128}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (\<lambda> n. if n \<in> {10, 11, 12} then 3 / 12 else 9 / 12)"
and h1 : "prob_space p"
and h2 : "indep_vars p (\<lambda>_. UNIV) (\<lambda> i. if i \<in> {1..4} then 4 else 0)"
shows  "prob (\<Inter>i\<in>{1..4}. {x. h2 x i = (if i \<in> {1..2} then 2 else 1)}) = 27 / 128"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 4 12-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that the number of dice showing a two digit number is equal to the number of dice showing a one digit number? Express your answer as a common fraction. (Assume that the numbers on the 12 sides are the numbers from 1 to 12 expressed in decimal.) The final Answer is \dfrac{27}{128}
 ### Proof
 Since 9 out of the 12 possible results are one digit numbers, each die will show a one digit number with probability of $\frac{3}{4}$ and a two digit number with probability of $\frac{1}{4}$. The probability that two particular dice will show 2 two digit numbers and 2 one digit numbers is thus $\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^2\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^2$.
 There are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ ways to select which two dice will show one digit numbers, so we multiply to get the probability that we want: $6\cdot\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^2\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^2=\dfrac{54}{256}=\boxed{\dfrac{27}{128}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (\<lambda> n. if n \<in> {10, 11, 12} then 3 / 12 else 9 / 12)"
and h1 : "prob_space p"
and h2 : "indep_vars p (\<lambda>_. UNIV) (\<lambda> i. if i \<in> {1..4} then 4 else 0)"
shows  "prob (\<Inter>i\<in>{1..4}. {x. h2 x i = (if i \<in> {1..2} then 2 else 1)}) = 27 / 128"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: There is a probability space with a probability function $p$. The probability function $p$ assigns a probability of $\frac{3}{12}$ to the outcomes 10, 11, and 12, and a probability of $\frac{9}{12}$ to all other outcomes. There are 4 independent variables, each taking values from the set $\{1, 2, 3, 4\}$ for the first two variables and $\{0\}$ for the other two variables. Find the probability that the first two independent variables take the value 2 and the other two independent variables take the value 1. The final answer is $\frac{27}{128}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob_1_digit prob_2_digit :: real
assumes h0 : "prob_1_digit = 9 / 12"
and h1 : "prob_2_digit = 3 / 12"
shows  "((prob_1_digit ^ 2) * (prob_2_digit ^ 2)) * (4 choose 2) = 27 / 128"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 4 12-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that the number of dice showing a two digit number is equal to the number of dice showing a one digit number? Express your answer as a common fraction. (Assume that the numbers on the 12 sides are the numbers from 1 to 12 expressed in decimal.) The final Answer is \dfrac{27}{128}
 ### Proof
 Since 9 out of the 12 possible results are one digit numbers, each die will show a one digit number with probability of $\frac{3}{4}$ and a two digit number with probability of $\frac{1}{4}$. The probability that two particular dice will show 2 two digit numbers and 2 one digit numbers is thus $\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^2\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^2$.
 There are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ ways to select which two dice will show one digit numbers, so we multiply to get the probability that we want: $6\cdot\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^2\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^2=\dfrac{54}{256}=\boxed{\dfrac{27}{128}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes prob_1_digit prob_2_digit :: real
assumes h0 : "prob_1_digit = 9 / 12"
and h1 : "prob_2_digit = 3 / 12"
shows  "((prob_1_digit ^ 2) * (prob_2_digit ^ 2)) * (4 choose 2) = 27 / 128"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given that the probability of a 1-digit number occurring is $\frac{9}{12}$ and the probability of a 2-digit number occurring is $\frac{3}{12}$, find the value of the expression $\left(\frac{9}{12}\right)^2 \cdot \left(\frac{3}{12}\right)^2 \cdot \binom{4}{2}$. The final answer is $\frac{27}{128}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum>k \<in> {0..4}. (binomial_coefficient 4 k) * (1/3)^k * (2/3)^(4-k))"
shows  "P = 27 / 128"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 4 12-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that the number of dice showing a two digit number is equal to the number of dice showing a one digit number? Express your answer as a common fraction. (Assume that the numbers on the 12 sides are the numbers from 1 to 12 expressed in decimal.) The final Answer is \dfrac{27}{128}
 ### Proof
 Since 9 out of the 12 possible results are one digit numbers, each die will show a one digit number with probability of $\frac{3}{4}$ and a two digit number with probability of $\frac{1}{4}$. The probability that two particular dice will show 2 two digit numbers and 2 one digit numbers is thus $\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^2\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^2$.
 There are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ ways to select which two dice will show one digit numbers, so we multiply to get the probability that we want: $6\cdot\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^2\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^2=\dfrac{54}{256}=\boxed{\dfrac{27}{128}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum>k \<in> {0..4}. (binomial_coefficient 4 k) * (1/3)^k * (2/3)^(4-k))"
shows  "P = 27 / 128"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Compute the probability of exactly $k$ successes in 4 Bernoulli trials with a success rate of $\frac{1}{3}$. The final answer is $\frac{27}{128}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "P = prob (\<lambda>(a, b, c, d). count [a, b, c, d] (\<lambda>x. x \<ge> 10) = count [a, b, c, d] (\<lambda>x. x < 10))"
and h1 : "all_dice_outcomes = {1..12} ^ 4"
and h2 : "prob = (\<lambda>A. card A / card all_dice_outcomes)"
shows  "P = 27 / 128"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 4 12-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that the number of dice showing a two digit number is equal to the number of dice showing a one digit number? Express your answer as a common fraction. (Assume that the numbers on the 12 sides are the numbers from 1 to 12 expressed in decimal.) The final Answer is \dfrac{27}{128}
 ### Proof
 Since 9 out of the 12 possible results are one digit numbers, each die will show a one digit number with probability of $\frac{3}{4}$ and a two digit number with probability of $\frac{1}{4}$. The probability that two particular dice will show 2 two digit numbers and 2 one digit numbers is thus $\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^2\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^2$.
 There are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ ways to select which two dice will show one digit numbers, so we multiply to get the probability that we want: $6\cdot\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^2\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^2=\dfrac{54}{256}=\boxed{\dfrac{27}{128}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "P = prob (\<lambda>(a, b, c, d). count [a, b, c, d] (\<lambda>x. x \<ge> 10) = count [a, b, c, d] (\<lambda>x. x < 10))"
and h1 : "all_dice_outcomes = {1..12} ^ 4"
and h2 : "prob = (\<lambda>A. card A / card all_dice_outcomes)"
shows  "P = 27 / 128"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Four dice, each with numbers from 1 to 12, are rolled. What is the probability that the number of dice showing a value greater than or equal to 10 is the same as the number of dice showing a value less than 10? The final answer is $\frac{27}{128}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes num_two_digit num_one_digit :: real
assumes h0 : "4 = num_two_digit + num_one_digit"
and h1 : "num_two_digit = 3"
and h2 : "num_one_digit = 1"
shows  "prob (num_two_digit, num_one_digit) = 27 / 128"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 4 12-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that the number of dice showing a two digit number is equal to the number of dice showing a one digit number? Express your answer as a common fraction. (Assume that the numbers on the 12 sides are the numbers from 1 to 12 expressed in decimal.) The final Answer is \dfrac{27}{128}
 ### Proof
 Since 9 out of the 12 possible results are one digit numbers, each die will show a one digit number with probability of $\frac{3}{4}$ and a two digit number with probability of $\frac{1}{4}$. The probability that two particular dice will show 2 two digit numbers and 2 one digit numbers is thus $\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^2\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^2$.
 There are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ ways to select which two dice will show one digit numbers, so we multiply to get the probability that we want: $6\cdot\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^2\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^2=\dfrac{54}{256}=\boxed{\dfrac{27}{128}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes num_two_digit num_one_digit :: real
assumes h0 : "4 = num_two_digit + num_one_digit"
and h1 : "num_two_digit = 3"
and h2 : "num_one_digit = 1"
shows  "prob (num_two_digit, num_one_digit) = 27 / 128"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given a two-digit number and a one-digit number, the sum of the numbers is 4. If the two-digit number is 3 and the one-digit number is 1, find the probability of the pair (num_two_digit, num_one_digit) as a fraction. The final answer is $\frac{27}{128}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob :: "real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> prob \<and> prob \<le> 1"
and h1 : "prob = (\<Sum>x\<in>{n. n \<ge> 0 \<and> n \<le> 4}. (binomial 4 x) * (1 / 9) powr x * (2 / 3) powr (4 - x))"
shows  "prob = 27 / 128"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 4 12-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that the number of dice showing a two digit number is equal to the number of dice showing a one digit number? Express your answer as a common fraction. (Assume that the numbers on the 12 sides are the numbers from 1 to 12 expressed in decimal.) The final Answer is \dfrac{27}{128}
 ### Proof
 Since 9 out of the 12 possible results are one digit numbers, each die will show a one digit number with probability of $\frac{3}{4}$ and a two digit number with probability of $\frac{1}{4}$. The probability that two particular dice will show 2 two digit numbers and 2 one digit numbers is thus $\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^2\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^2$.
 There are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ ways to select which two dice will show one digit numbers, so we multiply to get the probability that we want: $6\cdot\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^2\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^2=\dfrac{54}{256}=\boxed{\dfrac{27}{128}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes prob :: "real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> prob \<and> prob \<le> 1"
and h1 : "prob = (\<Sum>x\<in>{n. n \<ge> 0 \<and> n \<le> 4}. (binomial 4 x) * (1 / 9) powr x * (2 / 3) powr (4 - x))"
shows  "prob = 27 / 128"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A probability experiment can result in one of five outcomes, with probabilities given by the binomial formula. The probability of each outcome is determined by the formula: $P(x) = \binom{4}{x} \left(\frac{1}{9}\right)^x \left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^{4-x}$, where $x$ is the number of successes and ranges from 0 to 4. What is the total probability of all outcomes? The final answer is $\frac{27}{128}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "n = 4"
and h1 : "\<forall>k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 12 \<longrightarrow> P k = 1 / 12"
and h2 : "card {k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 12 \<and> k \<ge> 10} = 3"
shows  "prob_two_digit_eq_one_digit n P = 27 / 128"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 4 12-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that the number of dice showing a two digit number is equal to the number of dice showing a one digit number? Express your answer as a common fraction. (Assume that the numbers on the 12 sides are the numbers from 1 to 12 expressed in decimal.) The final Answer is \dfrac{27}{128}
 ### Proof
 Since 9 out of the 12 possible results are one digit numbers, each die will show a one digit number with probability of $\frac{3}{4}$ and a two digit number with probability of $\frac{1}{4}$. The probability that two particular dice will show 2 two digit numbers and 2 one digit numbers is thus $\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^2\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^2$.
 There are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ ways to select which two dice will show one digit numbers, so we multiply to get the probability that we want: $6\cdot\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^2\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^2=\dfrac{54}{256}=\boxed{\dfrac{27}{128}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "n = 4"
and h1 : "\<forall>k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 12 \<longrightarrow> P k = 1 / 12"
and h2 : "card {k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 12 \<and> k \<ge> 10} = 3"
shows  "prob_two_digit_eq_one_digit n P = 27 / 128"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Assume there is a probability function $P(k)$ which assigns equal probability of $\frac{1}{12}$ to each of the integers between $1$ and $12$ inclusive. If we randomly pick a two-digit number and a one-digit number, find the probability that the first digit of the two-digit number is equal to the one-digit number. The final answer is $\frac{27}{128}$.
